body.p: The confidence interval can be described as:

multiple_choice.choice: A range of values used to estimate a population parameter of interest.
A statistic that measures how far the sample mean of the data is likely to be from the population mean.
A statistic that tests the results of a project to see if you have conclusive results that have meaning.

feedback.p: Correct: This is a range of values based on results from the sample data.
Incorrect: This is the standard error.
Incorrect: This is a hypothesis test.

body.p: You are predicting the summer camp spending for families in your city. You predict that the summer camp enrollment expenses will be more than $250 per family per week unlike last year when it was $250 per week. What is the null hypothesis in this scenario:

multiple_choice.choice: H0 :Mean summer camp expenditure per family/week = $250.00.
H0 :Mean summer camp expenditure per family/week> $250.00.
H0 :Mean summer camp expenditure per family/week is much less than $250.00.

feedback.p: Correct: Your null hypothesis is the status quo.
Incorrect: This is your alternative hypothesis.
Incorrect: If you discover this, then it would also be an alternative hypothesis to your null.

body.p: Which statement below is true about statistical inference techniques:

multiple_choice.choice: The sampling distribution of the sample mean should be normally distributed.
A confidence interval for the sample mean and the sample proportion can be derived as the population mean multiplied by the margin of error.
The sampling distribution is the same as one sample mean.

feedback.p: Correct: Most statistical inference techniques work best with normally distributed data.
Incorrect: The confidence interval for the population mean and population proportion is the point estimate (sample mean) +/- margin of error.
Incorrect: The sampling distribution can be seen as the sample means of different samples drawn from the population.
